DataWhale Easy-Vibe: Zero to Hero Vibe Coding with Project-Based Learning

Jan 6, 2026
Vibe Sparking

DataWhale Easy-Vibe: Zero to Hero Vibe Coding with Project-Based Learning

Section titled “DataWhale Easy-Vibe: Zero to Hero Vibe Coding with Project-Based Learning”

In 2025, AI programming has entered a new era. While more developers are using AI to write code, many struggle to move beyond toy projects. The DataWhale Easy-Vibe project addresses this gap with a comprehensive, project-based curriculum for mastering vibe coding - the art of collaborating with AI to build production-ready applications.

Overview

Section titled “Overview”

Repository: datawhalechina/easy-vibe

Stats:

Easy-Vibe is a Chinese-language open-source curriculum that teaches you to become a one-person team - handling frontend, backend, AI algorithm development, and product management simultaneously through AI-powered development.

What is Vibe Coding?

Section titled “What is Vibe Coding?”

Vibe coding represents a paradigm shift in software development:

  • Traditional coding: You write every line manually
  • Vibe coding: You orchestrate AI tools to generate, review, and refine code while focusing on product vision and architecture

The key insight: You become the conductor, not the musician.

Why Easy-Vibe Stands Out

Section titled “Why Easy-Vibe Stands Out”

1. Project-Based Learning Structure

Section titled “1. Project-Based Learning Structure”

Unlike tutorials that focus on isolated concepts, Easy-Vibe uses 9 progressive projects across 3 stages:

Stage 1: Local Foundation (Beginner)

Section titled “Stage 1: Local Foundation (Beginner)”
  • Project 1: Build a Snake Game - Web AI programming basics, API integration
  • Project 2: Explore AI Tool Boundaries - Prompt engineering, image/video generation APIs
  • Project 3: Dify & Knowledge Base Integration - RAG, workflow orchestration

Stage 2: Database & Full-Stack Deployment (Intermediate)

Section titled “Stage 2: Database & Full-Stack Deployment (Intermediate)”
  • Project 4: Hogwarts Portrait Generator - Frontend prototyping to code, AI IDE basics
  • Project 5: Database to Supabase - JSON, backend services, authentication, edge functions
  • Project 6: Product Thinking First - Product思维, abstraction, user needs

Stage 3: Modern Full-Stack Applications (Advanced)

Section titled “Stage 3: Modern Full-Stack Applications (Advanced)”
  • Project 7: Modern Application - UI Design
  • Project 8: Modern Application - Feature Design
  • Project 9: Modern Application - Full-Stack Implementation

2. Comprehensive Extension Knowledge

Section titled “2. Comprehensive Extension Knowledge”

11 supplementary modules covering essential development foundations:

ModuleTopicsDifficulty
Git & GitHubVersion control, collaboration, SSHBeginner
API BasicsHTTP, requests/responses, third-party integrationBeginner
AI DictionaryLLM/image/audio/video models, AI engineering landscapeBeginner
AI IDE & TraeIDE concepts, Trae tool practical guideBeginner
RAG PrinciplesDocument chunking, indexing, enterprise solutionsIntermediate
Zeabur DeploymentWeb app deployment, Zeabur platformIntermediate
CLI AI ToolsTerminal, Claude Code/CodexIntermediate
MCP & SkillsMCP protocol, ClaudeCode Skills, tool extensionsIntermediate
Trae SOLO ModePRD generation, requirements-driven developmentIntermediate
Vibe Coding TasteTDD, checkpoints, constraintsAdvanced
Long-Running ToolsAutomation, task management, CLI stabilityAdvanced

3. Target Audience

Section titled “3. Target Audience”

The curriculum is designed for:

Librarian: Local CLI Tool for Coding Agents to Search Developer Documentation

Jan 6, 2026
Vibe Sparking

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

AI coding assistants are powerful, but they often work with outdated or incomplete documentation. Librarian solves this problem by fetching and searching up-to-date developer documentation locally on your machine, giving AI agents real context so they stop guessing and write better code.

GitHub: https://github.com/iannuttall/librarian

Librarian supports both GitHub repositories and public websites, making it a versatile tool for keeping your AI assistant’s knowledge fresh and accurate.

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”

Local Documentation Management

Section titled “Local Documentation Management”
  • Fetch docs from GitHub repos - Clone and index documentation from any public repository
  • Crawl public websites - Automatically discover and index docs from llms.txt, sitemap.xml, or robots.txt
  • Hybrid search - Combine word search with semantic vector search for best results
  • Version-aware - Track documentation versions to avoid mixed results

AI Agent Integration

Section titled “AI Agent Integration”
  • MCP Server - Built-in Model Context Protocol server for seamless integration
  • Agent skills - Pre-built skills for Codex, Claude Code, and Factory
  • JSON output - Machine-readable results for automated workflows

Flexible Search Modes

Section titled “Flexible Search Modes”
  • Hybrid search - Word + meaning (default, most accurate)
  • Word search - Traditional keyword matching
  • Vector search - Pure semantic similarity

Quick Start

Section titled “Quick Start”

Installation

Section titled “Installation”

During setup, you can choose to install globally. If global install is selected, use librarian directly. Otherwise, use ./librarian.

Librarian includes a built-in MCP server for integration with AI coding assistants:

  • search - Search documentation with mode options (word/vector/hybrid)
  • library - Find and list libraries/versions
  • get - Retrieve specific documentation

  • Note: Codex web and iOS don’t support direct invocation yet

Section titled “Configuration”

Configuration file: ~/.config/librarian/config.yml

Important Notes

Section titled “Important Notes”
  • Setup downloads a local embedding model for vector search
  • Public GitHub repos don’t require a token
  • Website crawling auto-detects CSR/SPA sites and uses headless Chrome
  • Chrome is auto-detected but can be manually configured
  • Run librarian setup to verify Chrome availability
  • If librarian command doesn’t work, use ./librarian

Librarian addresses a critical gap in AI-assisted development: keeping documentation context current and accurate. By running locally and supporting both GitHub repos and public websites, it gives AI coding agents the real-time context they need to write better code instead of guessing based on outdated training data.

Whether you’re using Claude Code, Codex, or building custom AI agents, Librarian provides the infrastructure for accurate, up-to-date documentation search.

VibeCoding: The Blueprint for Fully Automated Product Building in 2026

Jan 6, 2026
Vibe Sparking

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

A new paradigm shift is happening in software development. What started as AI-assisted coding has evolved into something far more powerful: VibeCoding - a methodology where developers and AI agents collaborate to build products with unprecedented speed and autonomy.

Coined by AI researcher Andrej Karpathy, VibeCoding represents more than just using AI to write code. It’s a complete reimagining of how software products are conceived, built, and shipped. In 2026, solo developers using VibeCoding methodologies are launching products in weeks that would have traditionally taken teams months to build.

Understanding VibeCoding

Section titled “Understanding VibeCoding”

What is VibeCoding?

Section titled “What is VibeCoding?”

VibeCoding is the practice of building software by describing what you want to an AI system and letting it create the product for you. Unlike traditional coding where you write every line manually, VibeCoding focuses on:

  • Intent-driven development: You describe the outcome, AI handles the implementation
  • Autonomous workflows: AI agents perform complex multi-step tasks independently
  • Iterative refinement: Quick feedback loops between human intent and AI execution
  • Context-aware assistance: AI maintains understanding of your entire project

The Evolution from AI-Assisted to Autonomous

Section titled “The Evolution from AI-Assisted to Autonomous”

The VibeCoding Blueprint

Section titled “The VibeCoding Blueprint”

Phase 1: Vision and Specification

Section titled “Phase 1: Vision and Specification”

Goal: Translate your idea into a clear, actionable specification

In VibeCoding, clarity of intent is your primary tool. You don’t write code - you write specifications that AI can execute:

  1. Define the problem: What pain point are you solving?
  2. Specify requirements: What must the product do?
  3. Describe the experience: How should it feel to use?
  4. Set constraints: What technologies, platforms, or limitations apply?

Example Specification:

Phase 2: Architecture Planning

Section titled “Phase 2: Architecture Planning”

Goal: Let AI design the system architecture

Modern AI coding assistants (Claude Code, Cursor, GitHub Copilot Workspace) can:

  • Design database schemas based on your requirements
  • Plan API endpoints and data flow
  • Suggest technology stacks optimized for your use case
  • Identify potential issues before writing code

Phase 3: Autonomous Implementation

Section titled “Phase 3: Autonomous Implementation”

Goal: AI agents build while you oversee and guide

This is where VibeCoding shines. Using tools like:

  • Claude Code: Long-context AI that can reason through entire codebases
  • Multi-agent systems: Specialized agents for frontend, backend, testing
  • MCP (Model Context Protocol): AI tools can directly interact with your environment

The workflow looks like:

Phase 4: Iterative Refinement

Section titled “Phase 4: Iterative Refinement”

Goal: Quick feedback loops for rapid improvement

VibeCoding excels at iteration because changes are conversation, not manual labor:

  • “Make the dashboard dark mode”
  • “Add export to CSV functionality”
  • “Optimize this slow query”
  • “Refactor this component for reusability”

Each request is handled autonomously by AI, while you focus on product decisions.

Core Components of a VibeCoding Stack

Section titled “Core Components of a VibeCoding Stack”

1. The AI Coding Environment

Section titled “1. The AI Coding Environment”
ToolStrengthBest For
Claude Code200K+ context, strong reasoningComplex architecture, full-featured apps
CursorVS Code integration, fastDaily coding, quick iterations
GitHub CopilotWide language supportEnterprise development
v0.devUI-first generationFrontend prototypes

2. Agent Orchestration

Section titled “2. Agent Orchestration”

Advanced VibeCoders use multi-agent systems:

  • Architect Agent: Designs system structure
  • Frontend Agent: Builds UI components
  • Backend Agent: Implements APIs and business logic
  • QA Agent: Writes and runs tests
  • Documentation Agent: Maintains docs alongside code

3. Context Management

Section titled “3. Context Management”

Your AI needs deep context about your project:

  • Project overview: Goals, constraints, patterns
  • Codebase understanding: File structure, conventions
  • Decision log: Why certain choices were made
  • Active work: Current task, blockers, next steps

This is often maintained in:

  • CLAUDE.md or AI_INSTRUCTIONS.md files
  • Project wikis or notepads
  • Specialized context tools (Claude Code memories)

Recommended Scenarios and Best Practices

Section titled “Recommended Scenarios and Best Practices”

When VibeCoding Shines

Section titled “When VibeCoding Shines”

Perfect for:

  • 🚀 MVP Development: Launch quickly to validate ideas
  • 🔧 Internal Tools: Build custom productivity solutions
  • 🎨 Prototyping: Explore multiple design directions fast
  • 📚 Learning: Understand codebases by having AI explain them
  • 🔄 Refactoring: Modernize legacy code systematically

Less Ideal for:

  • ⚡ Ultra-low-latency systems requiring hand-tuned optimization
  • 🔒 High-security environments requiring audit trails
  • 🏢 Enterprise systems with rigid compliance requirements

Success Patterns

Section titled “Success Patterns”
  1. Spec-First Development: Write clear specifications before coding
  2. Incremental Verification: Test each piece before moving on
  3. Context Maintenance: Keep AI informed about project state
  4. Acceptance Criteria: Define “done” before starting work
  5. Regular Reviews: Human oversight catches edge cases

Precautions and Challenges

Section titled “Precautions and Challenges”

Common Pitfalls

Section titled “Common Pitfalls”

Over-reliance on AI:

  • Don’t accept code without understanding it
  • Review architectural decisions
  • Maintain ability to debug without AI

Vague Requirements:

  • AI needs clarity to be effective
  • Ambiguity leads to rework
  • Invest time in good specifications

Context Loss:

  • AI forgets details over long sessions
  • Maintain persistent context files
  • Re-establish context for new sessions

Quality Control:

  • AI can write working but suboptimal code
  • Establish testing standards
  • Use code reviews even with AI

Managing Expectations

Section titled “Managing Expectations”

VibeCoding isn’t magic - it has limitations:

  • Complex reasoning: Humans still needed for novel problems
  • Taste and judgment: AI can’t substitute product intuition
  • Responsibility: You remain accountable for the code
  • Learning curve: Effective VibeCoding requires practice

  • Seniors + AI: Multiply senior developer impact
  • Juniors + AI: Accelerate learning and productivity
  • Specialists + AI: Fill gaps in expertise

Communication

When working with teams using VibeCoding:

  • Document AI-assisted work clearly
  • Maintain version control discipline
  • Share specifications, not just code
  • Establish review processes

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

VibeCoding represents a fundamental shift in how software is built. It’s not just about writing code faster - it’s about rethinking the entire development process around human-AI collaboration.

For solo developers and small teams, VibeCoding levels the playing field. You can now build products that previously required teams and months of work. For larger organizations, it offers a path to dramatically increased productivity.

The key to success with VibeCoding is clarity of intent. The better you can describe what you want, the better AI can deliver it. Invest time in specifications, maintain good context, and always review the output.

The future of software development is here - and it’s a conversation between human creativity and AI capability.

llm-madness: A Lightweight Pipeline for Training Small GPT Models with Web UI

Jan 4, 2026
Vibe Sparking

llm-madness: A Lightweight Pipeline for Training Small GPT Models with Web UI

Section titled “llm-madness: A Lightweight Pipeline for Training Small GPT Models with Web UI”

Training a custom GPT model from scratch typically requires complex infrastructure, expensive cloud resources, and specialized tooling. MaxHastings’ llm-madness inverts this assumption by providing a lightweight, end-to-end pipeline for training small GPT models locally, complete with a web-based UI for experiment management.

Introduction and Key Features

Section titled “Introduction and Key Features”

llm-madness is a Python-based toolkit that brings GPT model training within reach of individual developers and researchers. It provides everything needed to train custom language models: from BPE tokenizer training to model architecture design, from dataset management to run inspection—all through an intuitive web interface.

What Makes llm-madness Different

Section titled “What Makes llm-madness Different”
FeatureDescription
Complete PipelineData → Tokenizer → Tokenization → Training → Inspection
Web-Based UIVisual interface for configs, datasets, and run analysis
GPT ArchitectureClean, readable transformer implementation
Local-FirstNo cloud accounts or external services required
Experiment TrackingBuilt-in manifest system with provenance tracking

Core Capabilities

Section titled “Core Capabilities”
  1. Tokenizer Training - Configure BPE settings and build vocabularies from your own datasets
  2. Model Architecture - Design GPT-style transformers with configurable dimensions
  3. Dataset Management - Combine text files into versioned snapshots with SHA-256 hashing
  4. Training Infrastructure - AdamW optimizer with warmup, cosine decay, and checkpointing
  5. Run Inspection - Visualize loss curves, attention patterns, and token predictions
  6. Pipeline Orchestration - Chain stages together with automatic dependency resolution

Prerequisites, Installation and Configuration

Section titled “Prerequisites, Installation and Configuration”

Prerequisites

Section titled “Prerequisites”
  • Python 3.8+ with pip
  • PyTorch for model training
  • (Optional) CUDA/MPS for GPU acceleration

Installation

Section titled “Installation”

Quick Start

Section titled “Quick Start”

The web UI will automatically load and display your latest training run.

Project Structure

Section titled “Project Structure”

Recommended Scenarios and Best Practices

Section titled “Recommended Scenarios and Best Practices”

Ideal Use Cases

Section titled “Ideal Use Cases”

1. Educational Learning

Understand transformer internals with a clean, readable implementation:

  • Visualize attention patterns per layer and head
  • Inspect token-level predictions during training
  • Debug model behavior with trace mode

2. Rapid Prototyping

Validate ideas quickly without infrastructure overhead:

  • Proof-of-concept models for specific tasks
  • Synthetic data experiments
  • Baseline establishment for comparison

3. Domain-Specific Tokenization

Train custom tokenizers on specialized corpora:

  • Code repositories for programming languages
  • Medical or legal texts
  • Mathematical notation
  • Any specialized vocabulary

4. Architecture Research

Experiment with model configurations:

  • Layer and head count variations
  • Embedding dimension tuning
  • Modern variants (RMSNorm, SwiGLU, RoPE)

Daily Workflow Example

Section titled “Daily Workflow Example”

Here’s a typical session with llm-madness:

Step 1: Prepare Data

Section titled “Step 1: Prepare Data”

Step 2: Launch Web UI

Section titled “Step 2: Launch Web UI”

Step 3: Create Dataset Snapshot

Section titled “Step 3: Create Dataset Snapshot”

Use the web UI to create a versioned snapshot from your text file. The snapshot includes:

  • SHA-256 hash for reproducibility
  • Automatic train/validation split
  • Metadata tracking

Step 4: Train Tokenizer

Section titled “Step 4: Train Tokenizer”

Configure BPE settings in the web UI:

  • Vocabulary size
  • Special token patterns
  • Pre-tokenization options

Step 5: Configure Model Architecture

Section titled “Step 5: Configure Model Architecture”

Design your GPT model:

  • Number of layers and attention heads
  • Embedding dimensions
  • Block size (context length)
  • Optional: enable modern variants (SwiGLU, RoPE, etc.)

Step 6: Train and Monitor

Section titled “Step 6: Train and Monitor”

Start training with real-time monitoring:

  • Live loss curves
  • Sample generation at intervals
  • Perplexity tracking
  • Checkpoint management

Step 7: Inspect Results

Section titled “Step 7: Inspect Results”

After training, dive deep:

  • Attention pattern visualization
  • Token-level top-k predictions
  • Training log streaming
  • Compare multiple runs

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”
  1. Start Small - Begin with tiny models (6 layers, 6 heads) to iterate quickly
  2. Version Everything - Use the manifest system to track experiments
  3. Monitor Closely - Check loss curves and samples during training
  4. Compare Runs - Use versioned configs for ablation studies
  5. Cache Tokens - Enable token cache to avoid re-tokenizing large datasets

Precautions, FAQ, and Troubleshooting

Section titled “Precautions, FAQ, and Troubleshooting”

Important Considerations

Section titled “Important Considerations”

⚠️ Not for Large-Scale Training

llm-madness is designed for small, reproducible experiments. It’s not suitable for:

  • Training models with billions of parameters
  • Distributed training across multiple GPUs
  • Production-scale inference

⚠️ GPU Memory Limits

Even “small” models require significant GPU memory:

  • A 6-layer, 6-head model may need 4-8GB VRAM
  • Consider reducing batch size or model dimensions if OOM occurs
  • CPU training is supported but much slower

⚠️ Training Data Quality

The quality of your output depends entirely on your training data:

  • Clean and preprocess text before training
  • Remove duplicates and low-quality content
  • Balance your dataset if training on multiple sources

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: What model sizes can I train?

A: llm-madness is optimized for models in the 1M-100M parameter range. Larger models may work but will be slow without significant GPU resources.

Q: Can I use pre-trained tokenizers?

A: The toolkit focuses on training custom BPE tokenizers, but you can modify the code to load pre-trained tokenizers like GPT-2’s.

Q: How do I enable GPU acceleration?

A: Install PyTorch with CUDA support. The toolkit automatically detects and uses CUDA if available, falling back to MPS (Apple Silicon) or CPU.

Q: Can I fine-tune existing models?

A: llm-madness is designed for training from scratch. For fine-tuning, consider tools like Hugging Face Transformers.

Q: What are the modern architecture flags?

A:

  • use_rmsnorm - RMSNorm instead of LayerNorm
  • use_swiglu - Gated FFN (SwiGLU) instead of GELU
  • use_rope - Rotary position embeddings
  • use_sdpa - Scaled dot-product attention (CUDA only)
  • use_kv_cache - Faster autoregressive generation

Troubleshooting

Section titled “Troubleshooting”
IssueSolution
CUDA out of memoryReduce batch size or model dimensions
Slow trainingEnable GPU acceleration or use smaller models
Poor generation qualityTrain longer, use more data, or adjust temperature
Tokenizer errorsCheck input file encoding and format
Web UI not loadingEnsure all dependencies are installed

  • Complete provenance tracking

Boris Cheny's Claude Code Workflow Revealed: Running 15-20 Opus 4.5 Instances in Parallel

Jan 4, 2026
Vibe Sparking

Boris Cheny’s Claude Code Workflow Revealed: Running 15-20 Opus 4.5 Instances in Parallel

Section titled “Boris Cheny’s Claude Code Workflow Revealed: Running 15-20 Opus 4.5 Instances in Parallel”

“I’m Boris and I created Claude Code. Lots of people have asked how I use Claude Code, so I wanted to show off my setup a bit.”

— Boris Cherny, January 2, 2026

When the creator of Claude Code shares his personal workflow, the development community pays attention. Boris Cherny recently revealed his surprisingly “vanilla” yet highly sophisticated approach to maximizing AI-assisted development productivity.

Introduction: Compound Thinking and Verification

Section titled “Introduction: Compound Thinking and Verification”

At the core of Boris’s workflow are two fundamental mindsets:

  1. Compound Thinking - The CLAUDE.md file isn’t a one-time document but a continuously evolving knowledge base accumulated through daily work, code reviews, and problem discovery
  2. Verification Loops - Verification can improve output quality by 2-3x, addressing a core limitation in current AI programming: AI generates code well, but doesn’t inherently know if it actually works or provides good UX

Boris emphasizes: “A good plan is half the success” and invests heavily in upfront planning before switching to auto-accept mode for implementation.

Multi-Instance Parallelism: 15-20 Claude Instances Running Simultaneously

Section titled “Multi-Instance Parallelism: 15-20 Claude Instances Running Simultaneously”

Boris’s workstation runs at least 15 Claude instances concurrently:

EnvironmentInstancesPurpose
Terminal (iTerm2)5 tabsNumbered 1-5, using system notifications for attention management
Browser5-10 tabsclaude.ai/code sessions
TransportBidirectionalUsing & to transfer local sessions to web, --teleport for cross-session movement

This parallel workflow allows Boris to advance multiple tasks simultaneously, effectively orchestrating an intelligence matrix of AI agents.

Model Strategy: Opus 4.5 with Thinking Mode - Exclusively

Section titled “Model Strategy: Opus 4.5 with Thinking Mode - Exclusively”

Boris uses only Opus 4.5 with thinking mode enabled. His rationale is counterintuitive but proven:

“Although Opus is larger and slower, because of its strong understanding and accurate tool usage, it’s actually faster overall. No need for repeated corrections and guidance—it gets it right the first time. That’s true efficiency.”

The upfront cost of larger models pays dividends through reduced iteration cycles and higher-quality first-pass outputs.

Team Knowledge Base: Shared CLAUDE.md in Git

Section titled “Team Knowledge Base: Shared CLAUDE.md in Git”

The Claude Code team maintains a shared CLAUDE.md file committed to Git that every team member updates weekly. The logic is simple:

“Whenever you see Claude do something wrong, write it into CLAUDE.md. Next time Claude will know not to do that.”

This transforms team coding standards and collective experience into AI-accessible knowledge, creating a flywheel where:

  • Each code review improves CLAUDE.md
  • Improved CLAUDE.md automatically raises subsequent code quality
  • Knowledge compounds over time

Code Review Integration: @.claude PR Tags

Section titled “Code Review Integration: @.claude PR Tags”

During code reviews, Boris uses @.claude tags on colleagues’ PRs, instructing Claude to add discovered issues to CLAUDE.md. This is powered by Claude Code’s GitHub Action (installed via /install-github-action).

This is their version of “compound engineering”—every code review systematically improves the knowledge base, which then automatically improves future code quality.

Plan Mode: Discussion Before Implementation

Section titled “Plan Mode: Discussion Before Implementation”

Most sessions start with Plan mode (activated via double Shift+Tab). Boris discusses back and forth with Claude until satisfied with the plan, then switches to auto-accept edit mode where Claude typically completes implementation in one pass.

The pattern reinforces the principle: invest in planning, execute with confidence.

Slash Commands: Automating Inner Loop Workflows

Section titled “Slash Commands: Automating Inner Loop Workflows”

Boris has converted frequently repeated “inner loop” workflows into slash commands stored in .claude/commands/ and committed to Git:

  • Eliminates repetitive prompt engineering
  • Claude itself can invoke these commands
  • Team-wide standardization of workflows
  • Example: /verify command for validation workflows

Subagents: Common Workflow Automation

Section titled “Subagents: Common Workflow Automation”

Key subagents in Boris’s toolkit:

SubagentPurpose
code-simplifierSimplifies code after Claude completes work
verify-appContains detailed instructions for end-to-end Claude Code testing

Subagents essentially automate the most common workflows, ensuring every PR runs through standardized quality gates.

Post-Tool-Use Hook: Automatic Code Formatting

Section titled “Post-Tool-Use Hook: Automatic Code Formatting”

The team uses a Post-Tool-Use hook to auto-format Claude-generated code. Since Claude typically generates well-formatted code, the hook only handles the final ~10%, preventing CI format failures while maintaining code style consistency.

Permissions Management: Pre-Allow Rather Than Skip

Section titled “Permissions Management: Pre-Allow Rather Than Skip”

Boris doesn’t use --dangerously-skip-permissions. Instead, he uses /permissions to pre-allow common, safe bash commands in his environment, avoiding unnecessary permission prompts while maintaining security awareness.

Configuration is stored in .claude/settings.json and shared with the team via Git.

Tool Integration: Slack, BigQuery, Sentry

Section titled “Tool Integration: Slack, BigQuery, Sentry”

Claude Code integrates with Boris’s entire toolchain:

ToolIntegrationUse Case
SlackMCP serverSearch and post messages
BigQuerybq CLIRun queries for analysis
SentryDirect integrationFetch error logs

The Slack MCP configuration (.mcp.json) is also committed to Git for team sharing.

Long-Running Tasks: Background Agents and Stop Hooks

Section titled “Long-Running Tasks: Background Agents and Stop Hooks”

For extended tasks, Boris employs several strategies:

  1. Background agents for verification upon completion
  2. Agent Stop hooks for more deterministic verification
  3. Ralph-Wiggum plugin (originally conceived by Geoffrey Huntley)
  4. Sandbox mode with --permission-mode=dontAsk or --dangerously-skip-permissions for uninterrupted work

The Most Critical Insight: Give Claude Verification Feedback

Section titled “The Most Critical Insight: Give Claude Verification Feedback”

Boris’s most important insight:

“The most important thing is giving Claude a way to verify its work. With this feedback loop, final result quality improves 2-3x.”

The Claude Code team uses the Claude Chrome extension to test every change. Claude opens the browser, tests the UI, and iterates until code works and user experience is satisfactory.

Verification methods vary by domain—running a bash command, executing test suites, or testing in browser/mobile emulators—but investing in robust verification is universally applicable.

  2. Verification loops - Quality feedback improves output 2-3x
  3. Opus 4.5 exclusivity - Larger models are faster overall

  5. Shared knowledge bases - Team learning through Git-synced CLAUDE.md

The setup might be “surprisingly vanilla” in configuration, but the methodology represents a sophisticated rethinking of AI-assisted development—transforming from single-shot interactions to a continuously learning, parallel-processing, verification-driven development ecosystem.

SivaLabs Marketplace: Supercharge Spring Boot Development with Claude Code

Jan 4, 2026
Vibe Sparking

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Claude Code has rapidly become a powerful AI-powered development companion, and its extensibility through plugins and MCP servers opens up incredible possibilities for specialized development workflows. Enter SivaLabs Marketplace - a curated collection of plugins designed specifically for Java and Spring Boot developers.

Created by K. Siva Prasad Reddy (sivalabs), a well-known Spring Boot author and educator, this marketplace brings enterprise Java development patterns directly into your AI-assisted coding experience.

What is SivaLabs Marketplace?

Section titled “What is SivaLabs Marketplace?”

SivaLabs Marketplace is a plugin collection for Claude Code that focuses on Spring Boot application development using the Java, Spring Boot, and Spring Data JPA technology stack. It provides specialized skills that automate common development tasks while following established best practices and architectural patterns.

The marketplace is currently in active development (as of January 2026) and includes the spring-boot-dev plugin as its flagship offering.

Installation

Section titled “Installation”

Getting started with SivaLabs Marketplace is straightforward:

After installation, you can verify the plugin and its skills are available using the /plugins command in Claude CLI.

Available Skills

Section titled “Available Skills”

The spring-boot-dev plugin includes five specialized skills that streamline Spring Boot development:

1. spring-boot-package-structure-creator

Section titled “1. spring-boot-package-structure-creator”

Creates the recommended package structure for Spring Boot projects following best practices. This skill ensures your project starts with a solid architectural foundation.

2. jpa-entity-creator

Section titled “2. jpa-entity-creator”

Automates the creation of JPA entities with proper annotations, relationships, and best practices. Simply describe your entity requirements, and the skill generates production-ready entity classes.

3. spring-data-jpa-repo-creator

Section titled “3. spring-data-jpa-repo-creator”

Generates Spring Data JPA repository interfaces for your entities, including custom query methods when needed.

4. spring-service-creator

Section titled “4. spring-service-creator”

Creates Spring service layer classes with proper dependency injection, transaction management, and business logic separation.

5. spring-rest-api-creator

Section titled “5. spring-rest-api-creator”

Builds Spring MVC REST API controllers with appropriate annotations, request/response handling, and validation.

Practical Example

Section titled “Practical Example”

Here’s how you can use SivaLabs Marketplace to quickly build a CRUD REST API:

  1. Create a Spring Boot project with Web, Validation, Spring Data JPA, and H2 dependencies
  2. In Claude CLI, prompt: “Implement CRUD REST API for Person with id, name, email and phone fields”
  3. The plugin will automatically generate:
    • JPA Entity (Person.java)
    • Repository interface (PersonRepository.java)
    • Service layer (PersonService.java)
    • REST Controller (PersonController.java)

Each generated component follows Spring Boot best practices and integrates seamlessly with the others.

Included MCP Server

Section titled “Included MCP Server”

The marketplace also includes the context7 MCP server, which provides general library documentation lookup capabilities. This enhances Claude Code’s ability to reference official Spring documentation and other libraries during development.

Best Practices and Use Cases

Section titled “Best Practices and Use Cases”

When to Use SivaLabs Marketplace

Section titled “When to Use SivaLabs Marketplace”
  • New Spring Boot Projects: Quickly scaffold properly structured projects
  • CRUD Operations: Generate standard create, read, update, delete APIs
  • Learning Spring Boot: See best practices in generated code
  • Prototyping: Rapidly build working APIs for testing and validation

Tips for Effective Use

Section titled “Tips for Effective Use”
  1. Start with Package Structure: Use spring-boot-package-structure-creator first to establish your project layout
  2. Describe Entities Clearly: When using jpa-entity-creator, provide detailed field specifications including types, constraints, and relationships
  3. Review Generated Code: While the plugins follow best practices, always review and adjust generated code to match your specific requirements
  4. Use Context7: Leverage the included MCP server for accessing up-to-date Spring documentation

Compound Engineering Plugin: Official Claude Code Plugin That Makes Each Unit of Engineering Work Easier

Jan 3, 2026
Vibe Sparking

Compound Engineering Plugin: Official Claude Code Plugin That Makes Each Unit of Engineering Work Easier

Section titled “Compound Engineering Plugin: Official Claude Code Plugin That Makes Each Unit of Engineering Work Easier”

“Each unit of engineering work should make subsequent units easier—not harder.”

In traditional software development, every feature added makes the next feature harder to build. More code means more edge cases, more interdependencies, and more complexity. This accumulation of technical debt is the default trajectory for most codebases.

EveryInc’s compound-engineering-plugin for Claude Code inverts this paradigm. It implements a compound engineering methodology where each unit of work makes future work easier through a systematic learning loop.

Introduction and Key Features

Section titled “Introduction and Key Features”

The compound-engineering-plugin is an official Claude Code plugin developed by EveryInc that orchestrates AI agents to plan, write, review, and compound engineering knowledge. The plugin embodies a revolutionary approach to software development where:

  • 80% of effort goes into planning and review - ensuring thorough understanding before code is written
  • 20% goes into execution - leveraging AI agents for code generation
  • Knowledge compounds over time - each lesson learned feeds back into the system

Key Highlights

Section titled “Key Highlights”
FeatureDescription
Four-Step WorkflowPlan → Work → Review → Compound → Repeat
Multi-Agent OrchestrationParallel agents handle research, implementation, and review
Knowledge CompoundingLearnings are systematically captured and reused
Worktree ManagementIsolated development environments for each feature
Open SourceMIT licensed, fully auditable and customizable

Prerequisites, Installation and Configuration

Section titled “Prerequisites, Installation and Configuration”

Prerequisites

Section titled “Prerequisites”
  • Claude Code installed and configured
  • Git for worktree management
  • GitHub CLI (gh) for repository operations

Installation

Section titled “Installation”

The installation process is straightforward:

Initial Configuration

Section titled “Initial Configuration”

Once installed, the plugin provides four main workflow commands:

CommandPurpose
/workflows:planTurn feature ideas into detailed implementation plans
/workflows:workExecute plans with worktrees and task tracking
/workflows:reviewMulti-agent code review before merging
/workflows:compoundDocument learnings to make future work easier

Recommended Scenarios and Best Practices

Section titled “Recommended Scenarios and Best Practices”

When to Use Compound Engineering

Section titled “When to Use Compound Engineering”

This methodology excels in these scenarios:

  1. Solo Developers Building Products - One developer can achieve what traditionally required a team of five
  2. Complex Feature Development - Multi-component features that require careful planning
  3. Knowledge-Intensive Codebases - Projects where context and patterns matter significantly
  4. Long-Term Projects - Projects where compound effects have time to accumulate

Daily Workflow Example

Section titled “Daily Workflow Example”

Here’s how a typical compound engineering session flows:

Step 1: Plan (80% of the value)

Section titled “Step 1: Plan (80% of the value)”

The agent:

  • Researches the codebase and commit history
  • Scours the internet for best practices
  • Synthesizes a detailed implementation plan
  • Identifies potential pitfalls and edge cases

Step 2: Work (20% of the value)

Section titled “Step 2: Work (20% of the value)”

The agent:

  • Creates an isolated worktree
  • Implements according to the plan
  • Writes tests alongside code
  • Tracks task completion

Step 3: Review (Critical checkpoint)

Section titled “Step 3: Review (Critical checkpoint)”

Multiple agents:

  • Review the code independently
  • Catch issues and suggest improvements
  • Evaluate against established patterns
  • Verify all acceptance criteria

Step 4: Compound (The magic happens)

Section titled “Step 4: Compound (The magic happens)”

The agent:

  • Documents lessons learned
  • Captures new patterns discovered
  • Updates project knowledge base
  • Feeds insights back into the system

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”
  1. Never skip the Plan phase - This is where most value is created
  2. Always Review before merging - Multiple perspectives catch more issues
  3. Document everything - Future agents depend on this knowledge
  4. Trust the process - The compound effect takes time to manifest

Precautions, FAQ, and Troubleshooting

Section titled “Precautions, FAQ, and Troubleshooting”

Important Considerations

Section titled “Important Considerations”

⚠️ Learning Curve

The compound engineering approach requires a mindset shift. Traditional developers accustomed to “just coding” may find the emphasis on planning unfamiliar.

⚠️ Initial Investment

The first few cycles will feel slower than traditional development. This is normal - you’re building the knowledge foundation that future cycles will leverage.

⚠️ Tool Requirements

Full benefits require Claude Code with the plugin installed. The methodology is tool-agnostic in theory but optimized for this stack.

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: Is this only for solo developers?

A: No. While Every uses it to enable solo developers to build complex products, teams can benefit even more from the systematic knowledge capture and multi-agent review process.

Q: Does this work with existing codebases?

A: Yes. The Plan phase includes researching your existing codebase, making it effective for both greenfield and brownfield projects.

Q: Can I use this with other AI coding tools?

A: The plugin is designed for Claude Code, but the compound engineering philosophy is tool-agnostic. Some Every team members also use OpenAI’s Codex CLI.

Q: What happens if the plan is wrong?

A: The Review and Compound phases capture why the plan didn’t work, feeding that learning back into future planning cycles.

Troubleshooting

Worktree conflictsClean up existing worktrees with git worktree prune
Agent hallucinationsUse Review phase with multiple agents to catch issues
Slow performanceConsider reducing research scope in Plan phase

  4. 80/20 Planning-to-Execution Ratio - Inverts the traditional emphasis on coding speed

These aren’t demos - they’re products used by thousands of people daily for important work.

Ralph Wiggum: The Official Claude Code Plugin for Autonomous AI Development Loops

Jan 3, 2026
Vibe Sparking

Ralph Wiggum: The Official Claude Code Plugin for Autonomous AI Development Loops

Section titled “Ralph Wiggum: The Official Claude Code Plugin for Autonomous AI Development Loops”

Introduction: Ralph is Just a Bash Loop

Section titled “Introduction: Ralph is Just a Bash Loop”

In the world of AI-assisted development, a fascinating technique has emerged from the mind of Geoffrey Huntley. Named after the famously persistent Ralph Wiggum from The Simpsons, the Ralph Wiggum technique embodies a simple yet powerful philosophy: keep trying until you succeed.

As Huntley famously describes it:

“Ralph is a Bash loop” - a simple while true that repeatedly feeds an AI agent a prompt file, allowing it to iteratively improve its work until completion.

Now, Anthropic has released an official Claude Code plugin that implements this technique, bringing autonomous AI development loops to your fingertips.

Understanding the Ralph Wiggum Technique

Section titled “Understanding the Ralph Wiggum Technique”

Core Concept

Section titled “Core Concept”

The Ralph Wiggum technique is built on the principle of persistent iteration despite setbacks. Instead of trying to get everything right in a single shot, you let the AI fail, learn from its failures, and try again - automatically.

The traditional approach to AI-assisted development looks like this:

The Ralph Wiggum approach flips this:

How It Works Under the Hood

Section titled “How It Works Under the Hood”

The official ralph-wiggum plugin implements this using a Stop hook that intercepts Claude’s exit attempts:

The loop happens inside your current session - no external bash loops needed. The Stop hook in hooks/stop-hook.sh creates the self-referential feedback loop.

Key Features of the Official Plugin

Section titled “Key Features of the Official Plugin”

1. Self-Referential Feedback Loop

Section titled “1. Self-Referential Feedback Loop”
  • The prompt never changes between iterations
  • Claude’s previous work persists in files
  • Each iteration sees modified files and git history
  • Claude autonomously improves by reading its own past work

2. Simple Command Interface

Section titled “2. Simple Command Interface”

The plugin provides two main commands:

Starting a loop:

Canceling a loop:

3. Safety Controls

Section titled “3. Safety Controls”
  • --max-iterations <n> - Prevents infinite loops by stopping after N iterations
  • --completion-promise "<text>" - Defines the exact phrase that signals completion

Best Practices for Writing Ralph Prompts

Section titled “Best Practices for Writing Ralph Prompts”

The success of the Ralph Wiggum technique depends heavily on how you write your prompts.

❌ Bad Examples

Section titled “❌ Bad Examples”

✅ Good Examples

Section titled “✅ Good Examples”

When to Use Ralph Wiggum

Section titled “When to Use Ralph Wiggum”

✅ Good For

Section titled “✅ Good For”
  • Well-defined tasks with clear success criteria
  • Tasks requiring iteration (e.g., getting tests to pass)
  • Greenfield projects where you can walk away
  • Tasks with automatic verification (tests, linters)

❌ Not Good For

Section titled “❌ Not Good For”
  • Tasks requiring human judgment or design decisions
  • One-shot operations
  • Tasks with unclear success criteria
  • Production debugging (use targeted debugging instead)

Real-World Results

Section titled “Real-World Results”

The Ralph Wiggum technique has demonstrated impressive real-world outcomes:

  • Successfully generated 6 repositories overnight in Y Combinator hackathon testing
  • One $50k contract completed for $297 in API costs
  • Created an entire programming language (“cursed”) over 3 months using this approach

Philosophy Behind the Technique

Section titled “Philosophy Behind the Technique”

Ralph embodies several key principles that make it effective:

  1. Don’t aim for perfect on first try - Let the loop refine the work
  2. “Deterministically bad” means failures are predictable - Use them to tune prompts
  3. Success depends on writing good prompts - Not just having a good model
  4. Keep trying until success - The loop handles retry logic automatically

Installation and Setup

Section titled “Installation and Setup”

The Ralph Wiggum plugin is available in the official Anthropic Claude plugins repository:

Key files in the plugin:

  • .claude-plugin - Plugin configuration
  • commands/ - Command definitions (/ralph-loop, /cancel-ralph)
  • hooks/stop-hook.sh - The magic that makes the loop work
  • scripts/ - Supporting scripts

Advanced Usage: Ralph Orchestrator

Section titled “Advanced Usage: Ralph Orchestrator”

For more complex workflows, the Ralph Orchestrator provides enhanced functionality:

  • Web-based interface for managing multiple Ralph loops
  • Parallel execution of multiple tasks
  • Progress monitoring and logging
  • Integration with CI/CD pipelines

Learn more about Ralph Orchestrator

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

The Ralph Wiggum plugin represents a paradigm shift in how we think about AI-assisted development. Instead of treating AI as a one-shot tool, it embraces the reality that software development is iterative - and AI should be too.

By letting Claude fail, learn, and try again automatically, we unlock a level of autonomy that wasn’t possible before. Whether you’re building a REST API, generating test suites, or working on a complex multi-phase project, Ralph Wiggum gives you the power to define the destination and let AI find the path.

Practical Review: Building HeartPetBond App with Claude Code + BMAD + GLM-4.7

Dec 31, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Core Insight: Can Zhipu GLM-4.7 replace the expensive Opus 4.5 in the Claude Code environment? How does its 200K context window perform within the document-driven BMAD workflow? This post reveals the answers through the real-world development of the HeartPetBond app.

1. Motivation: Why This Review?

Section titled “1. Motivation: Why This Review?”

In the AI-assisted programming realm, Claude Opus 4.5 has been the undisputed king, but its high cost (approx. $15/1M input, $75/1M output) deters high-frequency usage. DeepSeek V3, while affordable, occasionally hits bottlenecks with ultra-long contexts (>128K tokens).

I aimed to verify Zhipu GLM-4.7, a strong challenger to DeepSeek V3, by developing the HeartPetBond app to test:

  • Long Context Capability: Can the nominal 200K Tokens Context support an entire project’s documentation and codebase?
  • Output Length: Can the 128K Tokens Output generate complex Flutter pages in one go?
  • Stability & Hallucination: Does logic crumble during continuous development over several days?
  • Cost-Effectiveness: How much money can it save independent developers compared to Opus 4.5?

Context: When using DeepSeek V3 with Claude Code + BMAD, I encountered errors like API Error: 400 ... maximum context length is 131072 tokens... when the context exceeded 128K. GLM-4.7’s 200K context might be the solution.

With over 10 years of Flutter experience and previous success generating the MoneyMind App using Claude Code + BMAD, I set out to see if this new model could handle the challenge.

2. Setup: Integrating GLM-4.7 into Claude Code

Section titled “2. Setup: Integrating GLM-4.7 into Claude Code”

Switching Claude Code’s “brain” is straightforward:

1. Install BMAD

Section titled “1. Install BMAD”

First, we introduce the BMAD (Building Multi-Agent Development) system, the core methodology that makes AI “understand engineering standards.”

2. Configure ZHIPU GLM-4.7

Section titled “2. Configure ZHIPU GLM-4.7”

Claude Code supports connecting external models via MCP or API adapters.

  1. Register and subscribe to the Zhipu BIGMODEL platform to get an API Key.
  2. Configure the default model in Claude Code (or related MCP settings) to point to GLM-4.7.

3. From Idea to Product: The Automated Workflow

Section titled “3. From Idea to Product: The Automated Workflow”

Following the BMAD workflow, HeartPetBond’s birth followed standard Document Driven Development. Here are the key milestones:

1. Initialize Workflow

Section titled “1. Initialize Workflow”

BMAD scanned the project state and provided a precise analysis:

2. Create Product Brief

Section titled “2. Create Product Brief”

After confirming brainstorming results, the AI generated the product definition:

It even locked in the tech stack: Flutter for cross-platform UI, GetX for lightweight state management, and Drift for local persistence.

4. PoC Verification & Performance

Section titled “4. PoC Verification & Performance”

After switching to GLM-4.7, I was most surprised by its “throughput speed” and “depth of understanding.”

1. Development Speed

Section titled “1. Development Speed”

In just 2-3 days, GLM-4.7 helped me complete 5 core pages for HeartPetBond (PoC phase):

  • Welcome Page: User onboarding.
  • Ready State: State checks.
  • Home Page: Core recording flow.
  • Settings: Complex configuration management.

The code pass rate was extremely high, rarely missing brackets or breaking logic even in deep Flutter Widget trees.

2. Token Usage

Section titled “2. Token Usage”

The cost breakdown is impressive:

  • PoC Phase Total: Approx. 300 Million (300M) tokens.
  • Estimated MVP: For 15 pages and App Store submission, estimated 3 Billion (3B) tokens.

Despite this massive volume, GLM-4.7’s cost is only about 1/7th of Opus 4.5. A Pro subscription (~¥200/month) essentially covers the MVP development needs.

5. Wrap Up

Section titled “5. Wrap Up”

The verdict from this field test is clear: Building mobile apps with GLM-4.7 + Claude Code + BMAD is entirely feasible and highly cost-effective.

✅ Pros

Section titled “✅ Pros”
  1. High Cost-Performance: GLM-4.7 is a perfect “affordable alternative” to Opus 4.5. It significantly outperforms DeepSeek V3 in daily coding tasks while remaining wallet-friendly.
  2. Long Window Stability: The 200K Context Window is real. It maintained clarity without “catastrophic forgetting” even after loading mass amounts of BMAD documentation.
  3. Engineering Ready: Works seamlessly with Claude Code’s toolchain to handle complex refactoring and debugging.

⚠️ Cons

Section titled “⚠️ Cons”
  1. Reasoning Minor Flaws: In very complex business flow designs, GLM-4.7’s reasoning chain occasionally misses a step compared to the meticulous Opus 4.5. This is manageable via human Code Review and clearer prompts.
  2. Multimodal Gaps: Current API support for multimodal inputs (images/files) is limited, requiring an additional zai-mcp-server configuration.

🔮 Final Verdict

Section titled “🔮 Final Verdict”

If you are an independent developer looking for a smart AI pair programmer that won’t break the bank, Claude Code + GLM-4.7 + BMAD is the combination to beat right now.

Life is compounding. Start building your bond today.

ClaudeCode Workflow Studio: Visual Automation Editor for AI Workflows

Dec 29, 2025
Vibe Sparking

ClaudeCode Workflow Studio: Visual Automation Editor for AI Workflows

Section titled “ClaudeCode Workflow Studio: Visual Automation Editor for AI Workflows”

Claude Code, Anthropic’s official CLI tool for AI-assisted development, has a powerful automation system through its .claude configuration files. However, creating complex workflows with multiple sub-agents, conditional branching, and user interactions requires editing markdown and YAML files manually. ClaudeCode Workflow Studio (cc-wf-studio) by breaking-brake brings a visual, drag-and-drop editor to VSCode, making workflow creation intuitive and accessible.

What is ClaudeCode Workflow Studio?

Section titled “What is ClaudeCode Workflow Studio?”

ClaudeCode Workflow Studio is a VSCode extension that provides a visual workflow editor for Claude Code. It allows you to:

  • Design workflows visually - Drag and drop nodes onto a canvas
  • Configure without code - Set up sub-agents, skills, and MCP tools through a UI
  • Export with one click - Generate .claude/agents/ and .claude/commands/ files automatically
  • Collaborate with your team - Share workflows via Slack with preview cards

GitHub Repository: breaking-brake/cc-wf-studio VSCode Marketplace: Open VSX License: AGPL-3.0-or-later Version: 3.9.1 (as of December 2025)

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”

1. Visual Workflow Editor

Section titled “1. Visual Workflow Editor”

The core of cc-wf-studio is its drag-and-drop canvas. Instead of writing markdown and YAML, you visually connect nodes to define workflow logic:

  • Prompt Nodes - Define reusable prompt templates with {{variable}} substitution
  • Sub-Agent Nodes - Configure autonomous AI agents with custom system prompts and tool permissions
  • Skill Nodes - Integrate Claude Code Skills from personal or project directories
  • MCP Nodes - Connect to Model Context Protocol tools for external integrations
  • Control Flow Nodes - IfElse (binary branching), Switch (multi-way branching), AskUserQuestion (user decisions)

2. AI-Assisted Workflow Refinement

Section titled “2. AI-Assisted Workflow Refinement”

One of the standout features is AI-assisted refinement. Instead of generating workflows from scratch once, you can iteratively improve them through conversation:

  1. Click the “Edit with AI” button (✨ sparkle icon)
  2. Describe your changes in natural language (max 2000 characters)
  3. The AI modifies your workflow incrementally, preserving existing work
  4. Repeat until satisfied

This conversational approach builds workflows through multiple rounds of feedback, with the AI maintaining conversation history and applying changes incrementally.

Example prompts:

  • “Add a Sub-Agent node that validates the input data”
  • “Connect the error handler to a logging Sub-Agent”
  • “Change the AskUserQuestion node to have 3 options: High, Medium, Low”

3. One-Click Export

Section titled “3. One-Click Export”

When your workflow is ready, click Export to generate:

  • .claude/agents/*.md - Sub-Agent definitions with system prompts and tool configurations
  • .claude/commands/*.md - SlashCommand definitions that execute the entire workflow

The exported files are ready to use immediately with Claude Code CLI. No manual editing required.

4. Slack Workflow Sharing (Beta)

Section titled “4. Slack Workflow Sharing (Beta)”

For teams, cc-wf-studio offers Slack integration:

  • Export workflows to Slack channels with preview cards
  • One-click import links for team members
  • Seamless collaboration without leaving your chat workspace

Installation

Section titled “Installation”

From VSCode Marketplace (Recommended)

Section titled “From VSCode Marketplace (Recommended)”
  1. Open VSCode Extensions (Ctrl+Shift+X / Cmd+Shift+X)
  2. Search for “Claude Code Workflow Studio”
  3. Click Install

From Open VSX

Section titled “From Open VSX”

The extension is also available on Open VSX:

  1. Install the Open VSX extension
  2. Search for “cc-wf-studio”
  3. Click Install

From Source

Section titled “From Source”

  1. Clone the repository:

  2. Install dependencies:

  3. Build the extension:

  4. Package and install:

  5. Install the generated .vsix file through VSCode’s “Install from VSIX…” option

Quick Start Guide

Section titled “Quick Start Guide”

1. Open the Editor

Section titled “1. Open the Editor”
  • Press Ctrl+Shift+P / Cmd+Shift+P
  • Type “Claude Code Workflow Studio: Open Editor”
  • Press Enter

First-time users get an interactive onboarding tour (available in English, Japanese, Korean, Simplified Chinese, and Traditional Chinese).

2. Create Your Workflow

Section titled “2. Create Your Workflow”

The left palette is organized into sections:

  • Basic Nodes: Prompt (templates), Sub-Agent (AI tasks)
  • Control Flow: IfElse (binary branching), Switch (multi-way branching), AskUserQuestion (user decisions)
  • Integration: Skill (Claude Code Skills), MCP (external tools)

Steps:

  1. Drag nodes from the palette onto the canvas
  2. Click a node to edit its properties in the right panel
  3. Connect nodes by dragging from output ports (right) to input ports (left)
  4. Configure node-specific settings (prompts, variables, conditions)

3. Save & Export

Section titled “3. Save & Export”
  • Enter a workflow name in the toolbar
  • Click Save to store as JSON in .vscode/workflows/
  • Click Export to generate .claude files

Node Types Deep Dive

Section titled “Node Types Deep Dive”

Prompt Nodes

Section titled “Prompt Nodes”

Define reusable prompt templates with template variables:

Variables are automatically detected and validated. At runtime, values are dynamically substituted.

Sub-Agent Nodes

Section titled “Sub-Agent Nodes”

Configure autonomous AI agents with:

  • System Prompt - Custom instructions for the agent
  • Tool Permissions - Choose which tools the agent can access (Read, Write, Bash, etc.)
  • Model Selection - Sonnet (balanced), Opus (complex tasks), Haiku (speed)

Skill Nodes

Section titled “Skill Nodes”

Integrate Claude Code Skills into your workflows:

  • Personal Skills - From ~/.claude/skills/ for individual use
  • Project Skills - From .claude/skills/ for team collaboration
  • Create New Skills - Build skills directly from the visual editor with a guided form
  • Browse & Select - Interactive skill browser with descriptions

MCP Nodes

Section titled “MCP Nodes”

Integrate Model Context Protocol tools:

  1. Select an MCP server from the dropdown (configured in Claude Code)
  2. Browse available tools or use search to filter
  3. Configure parameters with dynamic form generation based on tool schemas
  4. Real-time validation with error messages

Prerequisites: MCP servers must be configured in Claude Code settings first.

Control Flow Nodes

Section titled “Control Flow Nodes”

IfElse Node

Section titled “IfElse Node”

Fixed 2-way branching for binary conditions (True/False, Yes/No, Success/Error).

Switch Node

Section titled “Switch Node”

Variable multi-way branching (2-N branches) with dynamic case management. Ideal for complex routing logic.

Usage Examples

Section titled “Usage Examples”

Example 1: Document Analysis Workflow

Section titled “Example 1: Document Analysis Workflow”
  1. Upload Document Prompt - Asks user for file path
  2. PDF Extractor Skill (Personal) - Extracts text from PDF files
  3. Ask User - “Processing type?” → Summarize / Translate / Analyze
  4. Document Processor Skill (Project) - Team-shared processing logic
  5. Format Results Sub-Agent - Creates final output

Example 2: Code Quality Scanner

Section titled “Example 2: Code Quality Scanner”
  1. Code Scanner Sub-Agent - Identifies issues
  2. Ask User - “Priority level?” → Critical Only / All Issues
  3. Filter Results Sub-Agent
  4. Generate Fix Suggestions Sub-Agent

Example 3: Web Automation with Playwright

Section titled “Example 3: Web Automation with Playwright”
  1. Input URL Prompt - Asks user for target website
  2. Playwright Navigate MCP Tool - Opens browser and navigates to URL
  3. Ask User - “Action type?” → Screenshot / Extract Text / Click Element
  4. Playwright Action MCP Tool - Performs the selected browser action
  5. Process Results Sub-Agent - Analyzes and formats output

Internationalization

Section titled “Internationalization”

The Visual Editor UI and all exported files automatically adapt to your VSCode display language setting (vscode.env.language). Supported languages:

  • English (default)
  • Japanese
  • Korean
  • Simplified Chinese (zh-CN)
  • Traditional Chinese (zh-TW/zh-HK)

This ensures both the editing experience and generated workflows are accessible for international teams.

Limitations

Section titled “Limitations”
  • Maximum 50 nodes per workflow
  • AI processing timeout (default 90 seconds, configurable: 30s-5min)
  • Request limited to 2000 characters for AI refinement
  • Conversation history stored only during active session
  • Requires active Claude Code CLI installation

Troubleshooting

Section titled “Troubleshooting”

Workflow won’t save

  • Ensure workflow name contains only letters, numbers, hyphens, and underscores
  • Check all required fields are filled
  • Look for error messages in VSCode notifications

Export fails

  • Verify all nodes have valid configurations
  • Ensure node names are unique
  • Check write permissions for .claude directory

Can’t load workflow

  • Click refresh button (↻) to update the list
  • Verify file exists in .vscode/workflows/
  • Check JSON file isn’t corrupted

Section titled “Why This Matters”

  1. Lowers the barrier to entry - No need to understand markdown/YAML structure

  4. Integrates seamlessly - Exports work directly with Claude Code CLI

Official Apple code signed • macOS 14.0+ • ~3 MB • MIT License

What is Claude Usage Tracker?

Section titled “What is Claude Usage Tracker?”

Claude Usage Tracker is a lightweight, native macOS menu bar application that provides real-time monitoring of your Claude AI usage limits. Unlike web-based solutions, this app runs natively on your Mac with:

  • Real-Time Monitoring: Track session (5-hour), weekly, and API console usage
  • Official Apple Code Signing: No security warnings—installs like any normal Mac app
  • Automatic Updates: Built-in Sparkle-powered update system
  • Developer Integration: Terminal statusline for Claude Code users
  • Privacy-First: Local storage, no telemetry, no cloud sync

Chat UI Swift: A SwiftUI Chat Application Showcasing AnyLanguageModel and Swift-HuggingFace

Dec 29, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Chat UI Swift: A SwiftUI Chat Application Showcasing AnyLanguageModel and Swift-HuggingFace

Section titled “Chat UI Swift: A SwiftUI Chat Application Showcasing AnyLanguageModel and Swift-HuggingFace”

Building AI-powered chat applications on Apple platforms has traditionally required navigating multiple SDKs, APIs, and authentication flows. mattt/chat-ui-swift simplifies this landscape with a beautiful SwiftUI reference implementation that demonstrates how to integrate multiple language model providers through a unified API.

What is Chat UI Swift?

Section titled “What is Chat UI Swift?”

Chat UI Swift is a SwiftUI chat application created by Mattt Thompson, the legendary developer behind AFNetworking and NSHipster. It serves as a demonstration app for two powerful Swift libraries:

  1. AnyLanguageModel - A drop-in replacement for Apple’s Foundation Models framework with support for custom language model providers
  2. swift-huggingface - A Swift client for the Hugging Face API

GitHub Repository: mattt/chat-ui-swift Author: Mattt Thompson License: MIT

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”

Currently Supported

Section titled “Currently Supported”
  • Apple Intelligence - Native integration with Apple Foundation Models (macOS 26+) for on-device AI
  • Hugging Face Integration - Connect to Hugging Face with OAuth 2.0 authentication
  • Streaming Responses - Real-time streaming of AI responses for a responsive user experience
  • Chat Persistence - Save and manage multiple conversations

Planned Features

Section titled “Planned Features”
  • MLX Model Support - Download and run models locally using MLX
  • CoreML Integration - Support for CoreML-optimized models
  • GGUF Format Support - Load GGUF models from Hugging Face Hub
  • Model Downloads - Browse and download models directly from Hugging Face
  • BYOK (Bring Your Own Key) - Support for OpenAI, Anthropic, and other inference providers

Understanding AnyLanguageModel

Section titled “Understanding AnyLanguageModel”

The real power behind chat-ui-swift is AnyLanguageModel, a Swift package that provides a unified API for accessing multiple language model providers.

Swift 6.1 Package Traits

Section titled “Swift 6.1 Package Traits”

AnyLanguageModel leverages Swift 6.1 package traits to conditionally include heavy dependencies. This means you only compile the backends you actually use:

This results in:

  • Smaller binary sizes - Unused backends aren’t compiled
  • Faster build times - Less code to compile
  • Flexible deployment - Add/remove providers as needed

Security Best Practices

Section titled “Security Best Practices”

The AnyLanguageModel documentation includes important guidance on API credential security:

Never Hardcode API Keys

Section titled “Never Hardcode API Keys”

Malicious actors can reverse-engineer your app binary or observe network traffic to extract embedded credentials.

Recommended Approaches

Section titled “Recommended Approaches”
  1. Bring Your Own Key (BYO) - Users provide their own keys, stored in Keychain
  2. Proxy Server - Route requests through your authenticated service

Important: Apple App Review has often rejected apps using the BYOK model. Consider using a proxy server for production apps.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Chat UI Swift is more than a demo app—it’s a reference implementation for building AI-powered chat applications on Apple platforms. By leveraging AnyLanguageModel and swift-huggingface, developers can:

  • Use a unified API for multiple LLM providers
  • Switch providers without changing application code
  • Integrate Apple Intelligence alongside cloud models
  • Authenticate with Hugging Face via OAuth
  • Build beautiful SwiftUI chat interfaces

The project exemplifies modern Swift development practices: protocol-oriented design, async/await concurrency, and careful attention to security.

Ghostty Founder's Vibe Coding: A Conversational Journey with Claude

Dec 29, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Ghostty Founder’s Vibe Coding: A Conversational Journey with Claude

Section titled “Ghostty Founder’s Vibe Coding: A Conversational Journey with Claude”

When Mitchell Hashimoto, founder of Ghostty (the modern, GPU-accelerated terminal emulator), wanted to improve the macOS update feature, he didn’t just write code — he had a conversation. In a remarkable session he calls “vibe coding,” Mitchell paired with Claude to iteratively improve the codebase through dialogue, exploration, and shared discovery.

This isn’t about AI replacing developers. It’s about AI as a collaborative partner — and the transcript shows something beautiful: the AI catches things humans miss, the human provides direction and context, and together they build something better than either could alone.

What is “Vibe Coding”?

Section titled “What is “Vibe Coding”?”

Vibe coding is a conversational approach to software development where the developer and AI work together through natural dialogue. Rather than treating the AI as a command-execution tool, the developer treats it as a pair programmer — discussing, exploring, and iterating together.

In Mitchell’s session, captured from a real coding conversation on AmpCode, the flow goes like this:

  1. Oracle Consultation — Ask Claude to analyze code for improvements
  2. Discussion — Talk through the findings, make decisions together
  3. Implementation — Write code with Claude’s assistance
  4. Iteration — Learn from failures, adjust approach, try again
  5. Testing — Verify changes work, add tests for confidence

The Session: Improving Ghostty’s Update Feature

Section titled “The Session: Improving Ghostty’s Update Feature”

Mitchell started with a simple request: “Are there any other improvements you can see to be made with the @macos/Sources/Features/ Update feature? Don’t write any code. Consult the oracle.”

The “oracle” — Claude in analysis mode — identified several categories of improvements:

Critical Safety Issues

Section titled “Critical Safety Issues”
  1. Retain cycle in UpdateDriver.showUpdaterError — The retry closure captured self strongly, creating a memory leak
  2. Threading issues — UI-facing types should be marked @MainActor
  3. Progress value bugs — Progress values needed clamping to [0, 1] to prevent visual glitches
  4. Uncancellable timer — The “No Updates” auto-dismiss task could fire stale updates
  5. Swallowed errors — try? hid potential failures in startUpdater()

Areas Needing Unit Tests

Section titled “Areas Needing Unit Tests”
  1. ReleaseNotes parsing — Semver detection, git hash handling, edge cases
  2. UpdateState Equatable — Equality tests for downloading/error states
  3. ViewModel formatting — Text/icon/color mappings for each state
  4. Progress math — Division by zero, nil values, overshoot scenarios
  5. Auto-dismiss timing — Verify transitions and task cancellation

UX Improvements

Section titled “UX Improvements”
  • Add accessibility labels for assistive technologies
  • Clamp/abbreviate long error messages to prevent UI overflow

The Conversational Dance

Section titled “The Conversational Dance”

What makes this session remarkable is the back-and-forth:

Mitchell: “Stop stop stop. Undo all the main actor stuff.”

Claude: “Done! I’ve reverted all the @MainActor changes. The build now succeeds…”

Mitchell: “For the error message, instead of truncating, isn’t there a SwiftUI standard way to do this?”

Claude: “You’re absolutely right! SwiftUI has .lineLimit() and .truncationMode() for this…”

The human provides course correction when the AI goes down a problematic path. The AI suggests better approaches when the human asks questions. They learn from each other.

Key Improvements Made

Section titled “Key Improvements Made”

1. Fixed Retain Cycle

Section titled “1. Fixed Retain Cycle”

2. Clamped Progress Values

Section titled “2. Clamped Progress Values”

3. Made Auto-Dismiss Task Cancellable

Section titled “3. Made Auto-Dismiss Task Cancellable”

4. Added Accessibility Labels

Section titled “4. Added Accessibility Labels”

Simple, but critical — assistive technologies can now announce update status to visually impaired users.

5. Comprehensive Unit Tests

Section titled “5. Comprehensive Unit Tests”

The session added three new test files:

  • UpdateStateTests.swift — 150+ lines testing Equatable conformance for all states
  • UpdateViewModelTests.swift — 300+ lines testing formatting (text, icons, colors)
  • ProgressTests.swift — 150+ lines testing progress math edge cases

What This Session Teaches Us

Section titled “What This Session Teaches Us”

1. AI Sees Things Humans Miss

Section titled “1. AI Sees Things Humans Miss”

The oracle caught a retain cycle and progress value bugs that weren’t obvious. Code review tools often miss these too — having an AI analyze the code with fresh eyes catches different classes of issues.

2. Humans Provide Critical Judgment

Section titled “2. Humans Provide Critical Judgment”

When the AI suggested marking everything @MainActor, Mitchell recognized this would cause cascading compilation issues and asked to revert. Human judgment about architecture and trade-offs remains essential.

3. Iteration is Learning

Section titled “3. Iteration is Learning”

The session goes through multiple attempts:

  • First attempt at @MainActor fails → revert and try different approach
  • Manual error truncation → “isn’t there a SwiftUI standard way?” → use .truncationMode()

Each failure teaches something. The conversation enables rapid iteration.

4. Tests Provide Confidence

Section titled “4. Tests Provide Confidence”

The oracle suggested comprehensive unit tests. Writing tests alongside fixes ensures the improvements work correctly and prevents regressions.

5. Accessibility Shouldn’t Be an Afterthought

Section titled “5. Accessibility Shouldn’t Be an Afterthought”

The UX improvements weren’t flashy features — they were accessibility labels and proper text truncation. These make the software usable for everyone.

The Vibe Coding Workflow

Section titled “The Vibe Coding Workflow”

Based on Mitchell’s session, here’s a pattern for vibe coding:

  1. Ask, Don’t Command — “What improvements do you see?” vs “Fix this bug”
  2. Discuss Before Implementing — Talk through the findings, understand the why
  3. Implement Incrementally — Make one change at a time, verify it works
  4. Course Correct — Don’t be afraid to say “stop, undo that”
  5. Add Tests — Build confidence through test coverage
  6. Celebrate Learning — Each failure is a learning opportunity

Tools Used

Section titled “Tools Used”
  • Claude Code — AI pair programmer for the conversation
  • Swift/SwiftUI — Ghostty’s macOS frontend
  • Sparkle — macOS update framework
  • Swift Testing — Modern testing framework

Links

Section titled “Links”
  • Original Thread: AmpCode - Potential improvements for macos update feature
  • Ghostty: ghostty.org
  • Mitchell Hashimoto: @mitchellh on AmpCode

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Vibe coding isn’t about AI writing code for you. It’s about having a conversation with code — where the AI brings analytical superpowers, the human brings judgment and context, and together they create something better.

Mitchell’s session shows the future of programming: not humans replaced by AI, but humans augmented by AI — working together, learning from each other, and building better software through conversation.

The improvements to Ghostty’s update feature — safer code, better tests, improved accessibility — are a testament to what’s possible when developers embrace AI as a collaborative partner rather than a mere tool.

  • AI Development
  • Claude Code
  • Swift
  • SwiftUI
  • Open Source
  • Ghostty

LLMTornado: The .NET Library to Build AI Agents with 25+ Built-in Connectors

Section titled “LLMTornado: The .NET Library to Build AI Agents with 25+ Built-in Connectors”

Building AI agents and workflows typically requires integrating multiple APIs, handling different response formats, and managing provider-specific quirks. LLMTornado by lofcz simplifies this complexity with a unified .NET SDK that supports 25+ AI providers and vector databases out of the box.

What is LLMTornado?

Section titled “What is LLMTornado?”

LLMTornado is a provider-agnostic .NET SDK that empowers developers to build, orchestrate, and deploy AI agents and workflows. Whether you’re building a simple chatbot or an autonomous coding agent, LLM Tornado provides the tools you need with unparalleled integration into the AI ecosystem.

KestrelAI: Long-term Research Assistants with Self-Scheduling

Dec 28, 2025
Vibe Sparking

KestrelAI: Long-term Research Assistants with Self-Scheduling

Section titled “KestrelAI: Long-term Research Assistants with Self-Scheduling”

In the world of AI research assistants, most tools focus on quick, one-shot responses. KestrelAI takes a different approach—it’s a local-first research assistant that self-schedules and executes support tasks over long horizons, allowing you to stay focused on complex, novel work while it handles mechanical tasks in the background.

What is KestrelAI?

Section titled “What is KestrelAI?”

Kestrel is a local-first research assistant designed for long-running research tasks. What makes it unique:

  • Self-Scheduling: Automatically plans and schedules work, tracks progress, and pivots when stalled
  • Long-Horizon Execution: Runs for hours or days, providing auditable checkpoints for review
  • Local-First: Built to run on small LLMs (1-7B) via Ollama—laptop/desktop friendly
  • Source Provenance: Maintains clear records of consulted searches and their impact on findings

GitHub Repository: dankeg/KestrelAI Author: Ganesh Danke License: MIT

The Problem Kestrel Solves

Section titled “The Problem Kestrel Solves”

When doing deep research work, you often encounter time-consuming mechanical tasks:

  • Comparing tools and frameworks
  • Gathering real-world usage examples
  • Extracting performance claims from documentation
  • Assembling comprehensive comparisons

These tasks interrupt your flow on the actual novel work. Kestrel handles this background research, surfacing organized evidence when you need it.

Example Use Case

Section titled “Example Use Case”

Imagine you’re interpreting a frontier research paper and planning a novel study. You need to decide between Polars vs. pandas vs. Spark for your data processing.

Instead of spending hours manually researching, you tell Kestrel:

“Compare Polars, pandas, and Spark for data processing. Gather real-world usage, performance benchmarks, and use case recommendations.”

Kestrel then runs in the background:

  1. Searches for documentation and benchmarks
  2. Filters relevant sources
  3. Extracts performance claims
  4. Assembles a reviewable comparison

Hours later, you have an organized report ready for analysis—not scattered across browser tabs.

Architecture

Section titled “Architecture”

Kestrel uses a two-agent architecture:

Research Agent

Section titled “Research Agent”

Executes concrete micro-tasks:

  • Search → Retrieve → Filter → Extract → Narrow summary
  • Proposes specific follow-ups when evidence warrants it

Orchestrator

Section titled “Orchestrator”

Plans and coordinates the overall effort:

  • Schedules work across agents
  • Tracks progress and blockers
  • Pivots when stalled
  • Emits checkpoints you can accept or adjust

Orchestrator Profiles

Section titled “Orchestrator Profiles”
ProfileScope & BehaviorTypical Runtime
HummingbirdQuick breadth-first sweeps; targeted lookupsMinutes–~2h
KestrelMedium-horizon exploration with closely related branchesMulti-hour
AlbatrossLong-horizon, open-ended exploration with reviewsDay-scale+

The names are mnemonic—community-authored profiles with clear behaviors are welcome.

Tech Stack

Section titled “Tech Stack”
  • Backend: FastAPI
  • Frontend: React
  • Middleware: Redis
  • Model Runner: Ollama

More model engines and integrations are under development!

Installation

Section titled “Installation”

Prerequisites

Section titled “Prerequisites”
  • Ollama - Recommended for Apple Silicon (GPU passthrough limitations)
  • Docker Desktop
